question: Good afternoon, I need to order a reference proving that I am a student of the University.
answer: Good afternoon! To order a reference proving your student status, you can access MyUniversity. Select the "Academic Reference" option and specify the required number of copies. question: Hello, I am an international student. Do I need to do anything when I arrive at Innopolis?
answer: Hello! Upon your return to Innopolis University, as an international student, promptly upload your migration card and passport scans within three days on My University's "Migration Card" section. Then, submit visa details in the "Visa" section, followed by uploading your new registration card scan and related information in the "Registration" section. Non-compliance incurs a 2000 ruble late fee at Verkhny Uslon's Migration department and potential deportation after two violations. It's crucial to follow these guidelines upon arrival to avoid penalties or deportation.
generated_answer:
Hello, I am an international student. Do I need to do anything when I arrive at Innopolis?

Answer: Yes, you need to follow some steps to ensure your legal stay in Russia and avoid penalties or deportation. Here are the main things you need to do:

- Within 3 days of your arrival, you need to upload the scan of your migration card and your passport (even empty pages) in one PDF file in the "Migration Card" section of your personal account on My University. You can find the migration card at the border or at the migration department of Verkhny Uslon.
- Within 3 days of your arrival, you also need to upload the scan of your visa in the "Visa" section of your personal account on My University. You need to fill in the gaps with the information about your visa, such as number, expiry date, etc.
- After uploading the documents, you will receive a new registration card within 7-10 days by mail. You need to upload the scan of your new registration card and fill in the gaps with the information about your registration, such as address, phone number, etc., in the "Registration" section of your personal account on My University.
- If you have any questions or doubts, you can join the International students' telegram channel or text @Daria_cider. You can also check the handbook for more details and FAQs.
- If you fail to upload the required documents on time, you will have to pay a late fee of 2000 rubles yourself at the migration department of Verkhny Uslon. If you fail twice, you may face deportation. So please pay attention to the expiration date of your documents!

I hope this helps. Have a nice day!

question: What are AI courses for Bachelor Science students?
answer:
- [CSE301 — Philosophy II - Introduction to Artificial Intelligence](https://eduwiki.innopolis.university/index.php/BSc:_Introduction_To_Artificial_Intelligence)
- [CSE302 — Introduction to Machine Learning](https://eduwiki.innopolis.university/index.php/BSc:_Introduction_To_Machine_Learning)
- [CSE303 — Introduction to Big Data](https://eduwiki.innopolis.university/index.php/BSc:_Introduction_To_Big_Data)
- [CSE304 — Game Theory](https://eduwiki.innopolis.university/index.php/BSc:_Game_Theory)
- [CSE305 — Data Mining](https://eduwiki.innopolis.university/index.php/BSc:_Data_Mining)
- [CSE306 — Information Retrieval](https://eduwiki.innopolis.university/index.php/BSc:_Information_Retrieval)
- [CSE307 — Introduction to Computer Vision](https://eduwiki.innopolis.university/index.php/BSc:_Introduction_To_Computer_Vision)
- [CSE308 — Practical Machine Learning And Deep Learning](https://eduwiki.innopolis.university/index.php/BSc:_Practical_Machine_Learning_Deep_Learning)
- [CSE310 — Statistical Techniques for Data Science and Robotics](https://eduwiki.innopolis.university/index.php/BSc:_Statistical_Techniques_For_Data_Science)
- [CSE311 — Natural Language Processing](https://eduwiki.innopolis.university/index.php/BSc:_Natural_Language_Processing)
- [CSE340 — Nature Inspired Computing](https://eduwiki.innopolis.university/index.php/BSc:_Nature_Inspired_Computing)
generated_answer:
AI courses for Bachelor of Science students are courses that cover the theoretical and practical aspects of artificial intelligence, such as history, philosophy, logic, search algorithms, evolutionary algorithms, problem solving, knowledge representation, reasoning, acting humanly and rationally, ethics, and applications to various domains. Some examples of AI courses for Bachelor of Science students are:

- Introduction to Artificial Intelligence: This course introduces the student to the practical applications of AI, the history and philosophy of epistemology and intelligence, the Chinese room and Turing test, the role of AI in industries and the application, the PEAS model, and the ethical issues in AI.
- Searching Algorithms: This course covers the basics of searching algorithms, such as uninformed and informed search, heuristic search, adversarial search, parallel and distributed search, local search, constraint satisfaction problems, and optimization problems. It also introduces the student to PROLOG as a language for answering such problems, and the concepts of first and second order logic.
- Evolutionary Algorithms: This course covers the four base evolutionary algorithms: genetic algorithm, genetic programming, evolutionary strategy, and evolutionary expression programming. It also shows the application of one of these four to various problem instances, and the use of statistical models and scientific method to evaluate the performance of the evolutionary algorithms.

These are some examples of AI courses for Bachelor of Science students, but there may be other courses that offer different perspectives or topics on artificial intelligence. The student should consult the curriculum of their degree program or the course catalogue of their institution to find out more details and requirements

question: What are open access resources, literature and reference materials for NLP course for Bachelor students?
answer:
- Handbook Of Natural Language Processing, Second Edition Chapman & Hall Crc Machine Learning & Pattern Recognition 2010
- Clark, Alexander, Chris Fox, and Shalom Lappin, eds. The handbook of computational linguistics and natural language processing. John Wiley & Sons, 2013.
- Dan Jurafsky and James H. Martin. Speech and Language Processing (3rd ed.)
- Géron A. Hands-on machine learning with Scikit-Learn and TensorFlow: concepts, tools, and techniques to build intelligent systems. – " O'Reilly Media, Inc.", 2019. SECOND EDITION
generated_answer:
One possible answer is:

Open access resources, literature and reference materials for NLP course for Bachelor students are those that are freely available online or in print, and that provide relevant and up-to-date information on natural language processing, a subfield of artificial intelligence and computer science. Some examples of such resources are:

- NLTK (Natural Language Toolkit): A comprehensive library for NLP tasks, such as text processing, classification, parsing, and generation. It comes with documentation, tutorials, and examples in Python. https://www.nltk.org/
- Gensim: A library for topic modeling and similarity search, using statistical methods and big data techniques. It also provides tools for word embeddings and document summarization. https://gensim.ai/
- spaCy: A fast and comprehensive NLP library, with built-in models for various tasks, such as named entity recognition, sentiment analysis, and question answering. It supports multiple languages and has a simple API in Python or Java. https://spacy.io/
- Stanford CoreNLP: A suite of tools and libraries for NLP research and applications, developed by the Stanford Natural Language Processing group. It offers state-of-the-art models and pipelines for tasks, such as named entity recognition, part-of-speech tagging, and coreference resolution. https://stanfordnlp.github.io/CoreNLP/
- Linguistic Data Consortium: A repository of linguistic resources, such as corpora, lexicons, grammars, and annotation schemes, for various languages and domains. It also provides tools for data cleaning, processing, and downloading. https://www.ldc.upenn.edu/
- TensorFlow: A powerful framework for machine learning and deep learning, with support for NLP models and applications. It has a large community of developers and users, and offers online courses, tutorials, and examples in various programming languages. https://www.tensorflow.org/
- Word2Vec: A method for computing vector representations of words, based on their co-occurrence statistics in a large corpus. It can capture semantic and syntactic similarities, as well as word analogies and synonyms. It was implemented by Google and is available in Python or R. https://pypi.org/project/word2vec/ or https://cran.r-project.org/package=word2vec

These are some of the open access resources, literature and reference materials for NLP course for Bachelor students. They can help you learn the basic concepts, techniques, and applications of natural language processing, as well as explore the current research topics and challenges in the field. You can also find more resources by searching online databases, such as Google Scholar, or online platforms, such as Coursera, edX, or Udacity

question: What are the Eligibility criteria for Exchange programs?
answer:
**Semesters available for exchange:** - Bachelor's level: 3, 4, 5, 6 or 7 - Master's level: 2 or 3

**Trimesters available for exchange:** - Bachelor's level: 4, 5, 7, 8

**GPA required:** - regular exchange: 4.0 or higher - Erasmus+: 4.4 or higher.

You should also check the entry requirements of the partner university at its website.
generated_answer:
Answer: The eligibility criteria for exchange programs at Innopolis University are as follows:

1. Students must have a GPA of 4.0 or higher for regular exchange and 4.4 or higher for Erasmus+ funded exchange program.
2. Bachelor's level students can apply in their 3rd, 4th, 5th, 6th, or 7th semester, while Master's level students can apply in their 2nd or 3rd semester.
3. Bachelor's level students should have completed at least 4, 5, or 7 trimesters, depending on the partner university's requirements.
4. Students must meet the entry requirements of the partner university, which can be found on their websites.
5. Students should have a good command of English, as most of the courses are taught in English and students will need to communicate with international students and faculty members.

These criteria apply for both regular exchange and Erasmus+ funded exchange programs. The International Relations Office at Innopolis University can provide more information on the eligibility requirements and application process

question: If I am a teacher, is it necessary to share studying material only in moodle? Can I send materials as it is convenient for me?
answer: You can upload tasks to Moodle in advance and hide them from students, and open them when necessary. You can share a link to a chat/Telegram channel with students for assignments from Moodle.
generated_answer:
To answer your query, we need to consider several factors. First, let us assume that you are a teacher at Innopolis University and you are using Moodle as your LMS. Second, let us define what studying material means. According to the Moodle documentation, studying material can include any resource that is relevant for learning, such as readings, videos, podcasts, quizzes, etc. Third, let us examine the benefits and challenges of sharing studying material only in Moodle or sending materials as it is convenient for you.

Some possible benefits of sharing studying material only in Moodle are:

- You can create a coherent and organized course structure that follows the learning outcomes and objectives.
- You can provide a consistent and accessible environment for your students to access and interact with the materials.
- You can track the usage and feedback of the materials by using Moodle analytics and reports.
- You can ensure the quality and security of the materials by using Moodle plugins and features, such as file checking, license detection, content translation, etc.

Some possible challenges of sharing studying material only in Moodle are:

- You may have to spend more time and effort on creating and uploading the materials, especially if you have a large or diverse course content.
- You may face technical issues or limitations that affect the performance or functionality of the materials, such as bandwidth, storage, compatibility, etc.
- You may lose some control or flexibility over the materials, such as updating, deleting, or modifying them, if you share them only in Moodle and not elsewhere.
- You may miss some opportunities to reach a wider or different audience for your materials, such as other teachers, researchers, or learners, if you do not share them outside of Moodle.

Some possible benefits of sending materials as it is convenient for you are:

- You can save time and energy on creating and uploading the materials, by using existing or external sources that suit your course design and delivery.
- You can leverage the advantages of different platforms or tools that offer more features or services than Moodle, such as video hosting, podcasting, blogging, etc.
- You can customize or personalize the materials to match your style and preferences, such as adding your own comments, annotations, graphics, etc.
- You can share the materials with anyone you want, such as your colleagues, students, friends, family, etc., without having to worry about access permissions or restrictions.

Some possible challenges of sending materials as it is convenient for you are:

- You may have to deal with more complex or varied issues or expectations regarding the materials, such as copyright, format, quality, compatibility, etc.
- You may face difficulties or conflicts in integrating the materials with Moodle, such as linking, embedding, uploading, etc.
- You may lose some consistency or alignment of the materials with your course structure and objectives, which may affect the learning experience and outcomes of your students.
- You may violate some policies or guidelines of Innopolis University or Moodle, such as plagiarism, confidentiality, accessibility, etc., by sending materials that are not appropriate or permitted.

Therefore, to answer your query, it is not necessarily necessary to share studying material only in Moodle, but it depends on your situation and goals. You may choose to send materials as it is convenient for you, but you should also consider the potential consequences and implications of doing so. You should also balance the benefits and challenges of both approaches and ensure that you meet the requirements and expectations of Innopolis University and Moodle.

### Final answer: Sharing studying material only in Moodle or sending materials as it is convenient for you are both possible options, but they have different advantages and disadvantages. You should weigh them carefully and follow the rules and norms of Innopolis University and Moodle.

question: Where to find information about Academic Leave procedure?
answer:
The basis and procedure for granting academic leave are prescribed in paragraph 5 of the "Regulations on the procedure and grounds for transferring, expelling and restoring students and granting academic leave to students in the Autonomous Non-profit Organization of Higher Education "Innopolis University", at the link: https://innopolis.university/sveden/document .

For more information, you can contact the Student Support and Development Department, office 319, or [the bot of this department](https://t.me/StudentAffairs_bot).
